'''Continuuity''' is a cloud-based [[Big Data]] application platform for developers. Rather than simply providing another cloud service for writing and running [[Hadoop]] jobs, Continuuity allows developers to more easily build, deploy and manage Big Data applications on top of the components within the Hadoop ecosystem.<ref>http://gigaom.com/data/ex-yahoo-facebook-big-data-vets-launch-paas-for-hadoop/</ref>
Packaged in Single-node, Hosted Private cloud, On-premise Private cloud and Public Cloud Editions, Continuuity has built a cloud-based application runtime platform called the Continuuity AppFabric. The company also provides an SDK and suite of developer tools that promise "push-button deployment" from the developer's local single node AppFabric to the cloud.<ref>http://www.drdobbs.com/cloud/big-data-was-a-data-play-now-its-a-devel/240012595</ref>
==Product==
The company calls its product the Continuuity AppFabric, and it’s essentially a runtime for scalable Big Data applications. There are four core capabilities that comprise the AppFabric:<ref>http://gigaom.com/data/ex-yahoo-facebook-big-data-vets-launch-paas-for-hadoop/</ref> *Streams – allow users to send and store their data into the platform *App Containers – allow users to process their data in real-time *Datasets – data and tables that store and index the output of applications that run in the App Containers *Queries – allow users to access their data directly or write and deploy their own server-side query processors
These components sit on the Distributed Data Fabric that enables reading and writing to the underlying Hadoop infrastructure.
Continuuity AppFabric and a Software Development Kit allow developers to build applications in their IDE, run, test and debug them on their local machines, and when ready, "push to cloud" with a single click.<ref>http://www.datanami.com/datanami/2012-10-27/hadoop_world_special:_this_week_s_big_data_top_ten.html?page=8</ref>
Continuuity has simplified the entire Big Data application development lifecycle.<ref>http://devopsangle.com/2012/10/24/continuuity-launches-industrys-first-big-data-application-fabric/</ref>
The platform currently supports Java applications only — a natural first step given that Hadoop is written in Java — but Continuuity plans to support other languages going forward.<ref>http://gigaom.com/data/ex-yahoo-facebook-big-data-vets-launch-paas-for-hadoop/</ref>
From an integration perspective, Continuity supports REST interfaces.<ref>http://www.enterpriseappstoday.com/business-intelligence/former-yahoo-cloud-chief-aims-to-ease-hadoop-development.html</ref>
==Leadership==
Continuuity was started in 2011 by a team with deep domain expertise when it comes to Big Data,<ref>http://www.forbes.com/sites/davefeinleib/2012/10/23/big-data-startup-continuuity-comes-out-of-stealth-mode/</ref> including Todd Papaioannou, former chief cloud architect at [[Yahoo]] and entrepreneur-in-residence at [[Battery Ventures]], and Jonathan Gray, founder of personalized news streaming startup Streamy and more recently a top engineer at [[Facebook]], where he worked on the company’s Messages product.<ref>http://pandodaily.com/2012/10/23/continuuity-comes-out-of-stealth-promising-big-data-for-small-developers/</ref>
Papaioannou, along with cofounders Nitin Motgi and Jonathan Gray, were reportedly early adopters of the Hbase big data technology while working at companies such as Facebook and Yahoo.<ref>http://adtmag.com/articles/2012/10/24/continuuity-targets-big-data-developers.aspx</ref>
==Funding== The startup received $2.5 million in seed funding in January 2012 from Battery Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz, Ignition Partners, and a group of angel investors<ref>http://pandodaily.com/2012/10/23/continuuity-comes-out-of-stealth-promising-big-data-for-small-developers/</ref> On November 14, 2012, Continuuity, raised $10 million in a Series A round. The investors include Battery Ventures, Ignition Partners, Andreessen Horowitz, Data Collective and Amplify Partners.<ref>http://www.forbes.com/sites/tomtaulli/2012/11/14/continuuity-nabs-10m-to-drive-an-app-economy-for-big-data/</ref>
